First, **urgency**. People act when they feel time is slipping away. A “last chance,” a “limited offer,” or a “once-in-a-lifetime opportunity” all trigger the primal fear of missing out. You don’t ask them to hand over their possessions—you make them feel like they’ll regret it if they don’t act now.

Then there’s **authority**. People tend to trust those who appear to know more than them. Throw in a bit of jargon, a fabricated title, or a well-timed reference to a “senior partner” or “lawyer on retainer,” and suddenly they’re listening to you like you’re handing down divine truth. You don’t need to be rich or famous—just convincing enough to make them doubt their own judgment.

**Empathy** is your secret weapon. Show them you *understand* their fears, their dreams, their desperation. If you’re selling a fake investment, talk about how you *know* it’s hard to trust people these days. If you’re posing as a charity, mention how you *see* the weight on their shoulders. People give to people who make them feel seen.

**Scarcity** is another old favorite. “Only one left in stock,” “We can only help ten people today,” “This deal is only open to a select few.” It’s not just about what you’re offering—it’s about what they’ll miss if they don’t take it.
